reasoning: The critique targets a fairly central pillar of the essay’s optimism: that (absent major blockers) partial AM-convergence plus bargaining/trade among value-holders can steer society toward mostly-great futures. If post-AGI preference-shaping dominates, both “convergence” and “trade among stable agents” look much less reliable, so the attacked claims are central (though not totally, since the essay already treats coercion/memetics/lock-in as important and is not uniformly optimistic). The argument has moderate strength: it plausibly identifies an underemphasized failure mode (preference instability/manufactured consensus) that could seriously degrade the trade story, but it’s somewhat overstated because the position explicitly discusses conformity pressures, memetic power, self-modification/divergence, concentration of power, and blockers—so it’s not a clean reversal, more a demand to weight this factor more heavily. Correctness is mixed: it’s broadly right that power and persuasion can drive apparent convergence, but it overclaims that the essay is assuming this away rather than already acknowledging it as a major concern. The critique is clear, focused, and has little filler.
title: Historical moral convergence tracks power, so post-AGI convergence will too
